author: @imaniwilliams3140
text: I just wanted to take the time to let you know that this video really altered a lot for me. I‚Äôm a therapist who went to a PWI and therefore wasn‚Äôt exposed to individuals such as bell hooks. After watching this video, I ordered a few of her books and it has been life-changing for the better. I can tell that this is going to drastically alter how I facilitate psychotherapy as a black clinician and I have already begun ordering her books for several of my patients .Thank you for what you all do ‚ù§

When he was sharing what his mother taught it both broke my heart and made complete sense as a Black woman both who raised her son and taught ninth grade boys in Philly. Appreciate this conversation.

author: @MamiMelusine
text:
Olay you hit it on the head at 57:07  . In my teens and early twenties I just wanted a boyfriend because I could see how having one accorded girls more social value. Like one of the first things people would ask me, from the lady doing my nails to a new cool girl I met somewhere was if I had a boyfriend and I could see their estimation of me calculating as I answered. It wasnt until was older that I actually started really wanting a partner and defining what love might feel like and what kind of relationship and person I could experience that with.

And that kind of love is what F.D. Is talking about 1:10:16 that I have with my husband. Kudos to people who say their marriages aren‚Äôt hard but I think it‚Äôs really hard to stay on parallel paths your whole lives even when you are two individuals growing and changing at different rates. Love at that point isnt about ego or looking cute or presenting a certain picture to others, it‚Äôs constant decisions to care for eachother through that.

replies.author: @graceomalley4
replies.text: Well said

text: 1:19:07 it's hard for me to understand this take because there's so much more to life than romantic partners and I'd assume most people have family and friends that they can call and/or count on. I don't lol but I don't have romantic partners either, but from what I've observed from the outside looking in is that most people have other people in their lives that are close yet not romantic. There are other types of relationships and I think the problem with monogamy is that some people will throw all their other relationships away for that one romantic one - which is so unnecessary and can even be detrimental.

author: @pinballwitch5256
text: Just like with monoam relationships, polyam ones require open and clear communication. I was a very jealous partner when I was trying to force myself to be monoam, but when I started to realize I shouldn't be trying to make one person fit all my relationship needs, and I don't need to fill all of my single partner's, it helped me not just greatly manage my jealousy, most of it turned into compersion. I'm also on the asexual spectrum, which means I don't have to worry if I just am not feeling sex, and my partner wants to seek it out with someone she trusts. She tells me about these things, just like I tell her about my romantic interactions with a friend that has been blooming lately into much more. And my partner of 8 years loves seeing how happy it makes me. All relationships take work, but if you can't openly communicate, then you can't do that work. It's step one no matter what kind you have.

replies.author: @roselynholloway7863
replies.text: With you being on that spectrum do you ever desire the physical

replies.author: @keepingitkianatural

author: @harenmelan
text: This reminds me of a friend who got a divorce less than a year out from marriage. And I had been out of town at the time and asked why she married him. "He asked and I couldn't think of any really, REALLY good reasons I shouldn't." "Hun, if you're trying to think why you shouldn't and don't have reasons you SHOULD? You shouldn't marry that man." And after marriage he expected their lives to basically be homebodies rather than doing the things they BOTH did together over the week hanging out with mutual friends. While she was like "I don't think we should avoid spending time with people we both like."

author: @akg7915
text: I gotta say this video was so therapeutic to listen to because it‚Äôs been too difficult to find people willing to dig into such topics. I love me some bell hooks but it‚Äôs an endless struggle out here trying to find a single person that is also committed to growth and willing to admit and work on their own flaws. A lot of this spoke directly to insecurities and hurdles I‚Äôve been facing trying to date and helped me further understand a monumental break up I went thru years ago. Keep these healthy and productive conversations coming!

author: @AlexisCorchado-xy3cg
text: The end of this conversation was beautiful and ESSENTIAL. Relationships, love, and bonds can take on so many flavors, forms, and textures if we‚Äôre open and HONEST with the individuals we choose to share them with. One size never fit all and we‚Äôre doing more damage in the long run when we fail to acknowledge this. Used to believe in monogamy as the ‚Äúonly‚Äù way, even as a young child. At 43 years of age, I‚Äôm proud to say that things have changed. All of you contributed to this conversation with insights to cherish. Gracias mi gente üòä

author: @UhOhJacquinette
text:
37:52 I have been barking in any TikTok live. I can get in that although this may be an uneducated way to say it the little boys need to be involved in the wave of feminism. 


I have four male children and one female child . And I am watching in real time from my three year-old to my 17-year-old that I‚Äôm the only influence that is pushing any thought to them. Society, and all those outside of those who intimately know me and how I raise them teach them nothing but toxicity. My oldest son came into my room almost in tears because he was upset and frustrated at the thought that he‚Äôs going to be associated with ‚Äúmen‚Äù he expresses that the only way to be good, is to either except the role of the villain in conversation, be almost totally alone, or be complicit in the mess because he‚Äôs the teeny tiny minority. 

I hope that all the women who are participating in 4B and that will be thought leader in the next wave of feminism will include rhetoric for the little boys .


A real quick edit; 
When it comes to my female child, she is a rough and tough bob you over the head. Tell you what‚Äôs up call you on your mess type of girl and I make sure that that‚Äôs not stripped from her in many ways calling her brother‚Äôs misogyny out in front of them and her loudly walking them through it standing over her shoulder with most Disney movies cause I don‚Äôt want her to miss out, but I also need her to know that Anna is a fool for both dating Hans and Christophe.

replies.author: @keepingitkianatural
replies.text: Please continue to nurture that spirit in your daughter! Society will try beat that out of her, just like Sophia in The Color Purple. Protect that spirit! Good job raising these kids, because your son's introspection and empathy also needs fierce protection too.

replies.author: @UhOhJacquinette
replies.text: @ thank you so much. I thought that my comment was gonna be TLDR. üòÇ it‚Äôs really hard because I‚Äôm on working all the stuff in me trying not to make sure that she has to suffer too, knowing, like you said, that society is making a point to beat her spirit out of her, as it did mine. I‚Äôm working on building me back up. Your comment is a huge block for me to keep building on. Thank you again. ü´∂üèº

replies.author: @TheErikaShow
replies.text:
THIS! 
You remind me of my bff. She has a son, and she stays on his NECK with his emotional education. He is a tall kid, mature for his age‚Ä¶.as in he can sit down and have conversations with adults at 9 years old. She is raising her son to be a feminist through language, conflict resolution, and the real meaning of empathy. Recently, he was been teased by a girl in school. He retorted by making fun of her weight in classic school boy fashion.  I witnessed the most awesome conversation where my girl asked the boy if there was anything he didn‚Äôt like about himself. It went on from there, and seeing the boy put it together and think of other solutions‚Ä¶

Some days, we are on the phone as she is living her life, and I see a woman who can NEVER stop. Whether it is mother/son dates, where he learns how to treat a lady‚Ä¶and also what a ‚Äúlady‚Äù is‚Ä¶long conversations in the car about relationships and friendship‚Ä¶.yes‚Ä¶and he is 9‚Ä¶he has so much to say about his little life, and she doesn‚Äôt miss a thing. 

I see parents like my friend, who sees her son as a full being‚Ä¶.the. There are others who are attached to their sons in a toxic way, and will project all of their fears and dysfunction onto that boy‚Ä¶.using him as an emotional stop gap. This is why so many of my male gay friends felt so much pressure to ‚Äúbe a man‚Äù for their mothers. They were not taught that they are already born complete the way God made them‚Ä¶.they simply lack experience and perspective of an adult. Raising a kid is deep, af. 

Y‚Äôall have my full respect. My kids are cats‚Ä¶.lol. I‚Äôm just here as moral support.üòÇ

replies.author: @casadastraphobia
replies.text: I think being poly is attractive to toxic people, not that its not possible to be healthy in non-monogamous ways. I can say from my experience of being monogamous and having friends on both sides, the most toxic relationships I've ever seen were couples. Like, so much so its not even close. It kinda reminds me of he conversation about parenting styles. Not everything works or is even possible for everyone, but that doesn't mean "gentle parenting" is bad or whatever

author: @normandy2501
text: I don't trust nor hate my mom since we were never that close on an emotional level compared to my more affectionate father (and his whole side of the family), and my ideal representations of masculinity and overall human nature came from the original Lord of the Rings trilogy more than the rappers I wasn't really listening to until I got into underground hip-hop in the 9th grade. A character like Sam low-key set me up for a lot of disappointmentments in dating and friendships because of that culture of "trust no one" that I just innately couldn't relate to. I feel simultaneously lucky and unfortunate in certain ways as a result, but I can't help but be hopeful for the relationship between the masculine and feminine dynamic.

author: @MamiMelusine
text: Great video great analysis as always and the editing was fire. The segment about prosecutors made me think about George Gascon a progressive prosecutor who just got chased out in LA in the same election where Californians voted to keep slavery and overturned a proposition that increased the threshold for theft being considered a felony. The backlash to everything progressive we got done electorally recently has been so swift and heavy it makes your head spin and I know some of the older middle class black folks who voted for it, scared by reports of crimes all over the place that no one I know have experienced.

author: @sixtyblackmystictraveler
text:
30:13 I want to point out there‚Äôs NOT ONE HUMAN on this earth who doesn‚Äôt need therapy. We have trauma in how this society has been shaped, we have generational trauma, we have trauma alive and well throughout our entire lives, including what we pick up in utero because we are sentient beings (we are always feeling and sensing; it‚Äôs how the nervous system allows us to adapt to all shit, including fuckshit). All this to say ‚Äúattachment‚Äù, how we attach, if we attach to the people who are to care for us creates a future road map.

I also have to wonder if the women who attach to men who are in prison also like the idea that at least their prison man is ‚Äúfaithful‚Äù not accepting that the same way he connected to you is the same way he connects with OTHER women while in prison, not to mention the men he can connect with WHILE in prison.

replies.text: Well she‚Äôs quite ‚Äúsuccessful‚Äù, is she a millionaire? Possibly, but who really knows? She‚Äôs started modeling as a baby and acting from very young. Her Disney shows did very well. She‚Äôs done some small movie roles here and there, but I believe her bread and butter in recent years has been social media. author: @Wordsespecially3
text: There‚Äôs definitely a level of fetishisation from wealthy people to people who experience financial problems (poverty). In Halles case, it feels more like she relates to the YouTube come up of DVD seen as that‚Äôs how she got her big break. Less fetish and more like a grounding? Like she‚Äôs closer to where she came from w him. While Skai‚Äôs situation feels like she enjoys the stark difference between their lifestyles. Could be trauma from what she experienced w Solange‚Äôs son and his release of their s3xtape . Idk.

author: @seeing-real
text:
Excellent conversation but what exactly is the question here? The framing is off:  

1) Why are young women intentionally making a choice to have sex with fertile men that they don‚Äôt want relationships with‚Ä¶solely for the purpose of becoming pregnant? If that‚Äôs the case are we here to understand their choice and help them do it better? Perhaps they want babies but not a relationship at all? Can we discuss how they can further transgress and make this work better for them?

2) Why do they avoid or just don‚Äôt want healthy relationships? The conversation is clear that healthy men are few and far between while women are constantly groomed to accept men as they are.  So the conversation should be framed as: how to help women let go of patriarchal idealization.

None of them are choosing to be single mothers‚Ä¶and if they are then we can help them do it better and fully let go of the toxic dynamic with the guy rather than being shamed into performing a relationship that neither of them wants/and that is actually impossible because of men‚Äôs inability to feel and women‚Äôs inability to let go of a desire for motherhood.
